key_points: Thomas Lane, J Kueng, and Tou Thao, charged in George Floyd's death, request barring their trial from being broadcast.
Their lawyers reverse earlier stance favoring public broadcast, citing witness reluctance due to prior trial's publicity.
Lawyers argue widespread coverage of Derek Chauvin's trial compromised their clients' right to a fair trial.
Judge Peter Cahill, previously presided over Chauvin's televised trial, to decide on the livestreaming request.
Chauvin's trial broadcasting was a first in Minnesota, considered for future criminal trials considering its success.
Prosecutors support livestream of next trial, rebutting claims it would impair fair trial, highlighting public access benefits.
Lawyers for news outlets, including The Associated Press, argue against the ban, emphasizing public's right to monitor the trial.
Legal motions related to evidence requests and witness coercion allegations were also discussed.
Chauvin has been sentenced to 22.5 years in prison; all four officers also face federal civil rights violation charges.
The outcome of the livestreaming request and other motions is pending Judge Cahill's decisions.
